comments.commentBody:
It's been sixteen days day since the Republican/Tea Party has been elected and put in control of the House.

Today, House Republicans voted to ban earmarks. Great news - all of our problems are now solved. Hallelujah!

Sixteen days and they have not enacted any of the items contained in their Pledge to America - why not?

Sixteen days and they're done nothing to solve our economic problems and create jobs. Nothing. Nada. Why not?

Why is the car still in the ditch Mr. Boehner?

Unemployment is still at 9.6% and unchanged since election day November 2, 2010. Where are the jobs, Mr. Boehner? Where are the jobs?

Day Sixteen of Republican/Tea Party control. Be back tomorrow for a report on Day 17, and each day thereafter.

Does anyone out there realize that Rampers,Aircraft MX,Catering workers DO NOT clear secruity?  If it is required for passengers and crew, why not these work groups Rampers and Catering staff do not go through the background checks required by crewmembers and there is alot of turn over in these groups.  It's like locking the backdoor and leaving the front door open.

I consider myself an "average American" and as fare a I am concerned they can pat me down as much as they want if it will keep me alive. If it bothers some let them take Amtrack or Greyhound and let the rest of us be safe. I didn't aslk you to fly...so don't ask me to give up my safety if I decide to fly!!!
I resent the expert who questioned whether average Americans would tolerate this....speak for yourself and not for me. AMEN!
Thie is freedom going beyond the extreme.
EdB
Virginia
Just grow up.  Some stranger you'll never see again sees a blurry x-rayish picture of your body for a few moments or bumps around your private parts to help avoid a horrific tragedy.  So what.

Mr. Michael Chertoff this is addressed to you.

I would like to know why you for two years in a row signed several billion dollar purchase orders for body scanners from a particular company, and then once out of office - you were 'Homeland Security' Head - became CEO of the company that makes the scanners.

Isn't this illegal?

And, do you fly in private jets, pulling up to the airport in a black SUV, and simply getting on board, if you don't leave from a private field? Do you experience genital feelups? Alternatively, do you have your body photographed in exquisitely intimate detail each time you fly while you are bathed in radiation, by the TSA agents behind their little shield?

You know the manual to run the scanners your company makes explains in detail how the images are to be tuned by focusing on the genitals, that the images are saved. You also know, I am sure, that the government wants a 360 biometric scan of everyone... That the TSA is molesting people, hiring people who will do that job... and firing those who will not... solely in order to force them to go through the scanners - I am sure you know.

Do you ever lose sleep at night about having been part of the false terror alerts, the HLS policy which violates the 'Patriot Act'? Or more to the point, the staged operations - to force your scanners into the airports, before the malls, the stadiums, the schools? ... the 'underwear bomber,' Mutallab - who was, without passport or visa, LED ONTO THE PLANE by someone in a business suit - for which situation the State Department eventually had to admit responsibility?

Also: about 9/11, do you sleep well at night?

Let me know.

I understand your dual citizenship may play a part in a sense of disassociation from the American people, perhaps even disdain for the American people. I don't know; I have to get to know you a little better to find out.

I would like to talk with you.

How tragic that children have to suffer like this.

More money for research for such illnesses.

Thank God for Health Care Reform, so that children such as Lauren
will be able to secure health care rather than be denied the care they need
desperately due to a 'pre existing condition'.

Mr. Axelrod's championing of Health Care Reform is a huge accomplishment
and will help millions of children, born with various crippling disabilities
to have humane and competent care.

Republicans and Tea Partiers and general public, please think about who you wish to hurt when you considerattempting to repeal one of the most humane pieces of legislation in decades.

If we fail to educate our children we are doomed as a nation.  I am sickened by the flippant way our poiticians call for ongoing cuts.  There have been massive cuts to education in California year after year.  And the military budget?  Higher and higher every year.  I wish my income tax form came with a check list of where I wanted my tax dollars to go.  I'd assign 100% to what Republicans call "failing schools".  "Failing" schools need more money,  not less.
Maybe she can beat him in geography..then again, not!
my daughter cancelled her thanksgiving trip after seeing a little girl molested so my grandaughter would not be put in the same situation.

The TSA keeps claiming that a "majority of Americans" support the new machines and the new searches, but what exactly does that mean? A majority of the general population, a majority of travelers? I'd like to see polling done of people who travel at least somewhat regularly, perhaps once every 4 to 6 months, as these are the people who have to bear the brunt of such searches and who also reap the greatest benefit of any additional security they provide. If a majority of the general population does not travel by air more than once a year (if that?), their only incentive is to ensure that the one flight they take is absolutely secure, and so they will support any policy that appears to make them safer. But for those who fly regularly, there must be a rationale analysis. Given the fact that other than the so-called "underwear bomber" there has not been any other case of someone successfully sneaking an explosive devise onto a plane on their physical body, I question what exactly we're being protected against. As was the case with the so-called "shoe-bomber", this appears to be a mix of overreaction on the part of the TSA and an attempt to justify massive expenditure and demonstrate to the public that they are "doing something" - while we in the U.S. have had to remove our shoes (not to mention sandals and flip-flops) every time we pass through security, in the 9 years since that event Europeans have not had to do so and have not suffered any consequences as a result.

I am certainly concerned about radiation and intrusive touching of my person.

What really concerns me is how these tactics will be applied to children and, in particular, to unaccompanied minors. Will my 10 and 12 year old granddaughter and grandson be irradiated, traumatized, or both, if they fly cross country to visit me?

I can only hope that all senior government officials, including the SCOTUS Justices, are subjected to the same treatment as everyone else; they have no excuse not to be searched. If they like it, then it is OK for all. In fact, why don't they all go to National Airport and volunteer to go through this screening several days. Perhaps they can throw in a cavity search since the same logic would justify that also.

TSA is about out of options. If other adverse events happen, and they go to cavity searches there is almost nothing left other than for them to get much more intelligent.

The public can and should reject this kind of intrusive and demeaning action by the TSA.  They have rushed to put these machines in place when it has always been known that their effectiveness is second to profiling and pre-screening/pre-certification of travlers (i.e. the trusted traveler program).  We should demand better of our government and if protest and boycott are the only means to get them to listen, then so be it.

Who knew Archie bunker had it right when he suggested we simply hand guns to everyone entering the plane and pick them up on their way out. I will go one step further; we all fly naked. That way no one can hide anything.

Yes indeed, the terrorist have won. It does not help that the Obama administration, so terrified of being blamed for an attack by the usual suspects is willing to throw all rights out of the window. It does not help either that those doing the pat downs are not exactly America's best and brightest. Even worse, common sense has been throw out the window as to who should be searched. Is a ten year old American kid really going to be carry a bomb for Al Qaeda? What a mess.

This is nearly as absurd & humiliating as the five-minute nonsense from US customs officers we have to experience every time we enter the country. I know politicians feel as though they have to do something to look as though they're addressing the issue. But I can't help but feel that there are far more effective, less intrusive ways to protect our country.

I'd hoped a Democratic President would improve this situation. Perhaps one would have if they'd had more than two years of experience in Washington before starting a run for the Presidency.
So its official, the terrorists have won

I am no fan of the airline industry and my home airport as been a source of embarrassment for over 30 years of flying. I also don't have a lot of time for government workers on the City, State or Federal levels. However I need to report that a couple of weeks ago I flew out of PHL and as often happens I triggered the alarm on the walk-through scanner. The TSA people very politely asked if I'd consent to a pat-down and I did. The young man who did the actual patting was being trained and before each step of the process they explained in detail what I could expect. Yes, at one point the back of the agent's hand very lightly and very quickly passed by the briefs I was wearing under my trousers. And yes the young man passed his hand around the inside of my trousers at waist level. The whole process was very quick and very methodical.  At no time did I have reason to believe the agents involved in my pat down were getting any perverse pleasure from their work and at no time did I feel my privacy was being violated. The very professional and matter-of-fact demeanor of the TSA people was commendable.  Alarmist types are using interchangeably terms like "fondle" for "pass-over" and "grope" for "light touching". These are people who need to use juvenile terms for body parts they haven't grown up to respect and understand. When you hear an adult talking about his "junk" because he's too immature to use the word genitals you have to wonder exactly how he'd behave on a topless beach - if he ever got to one. Americans can't even ask for a public toilet - um "commode", "john", "head" - you know the euphemisms, you learned them as a kid - some people even still call a toilet a potty. The patting down of America - a terrorist's best hope?

This falls entirely in the lap of TSA! We, the travelling public have been incredibly cooperative for far too long. Perhaps, that is part of the problem, had "we" spoken up earlier many of the above issues may have been handled alng the way. Instead we were told to be quiet.

TSA has had more than 5 years to estblish themselves as a proven Government Organisation capable of protecting us as mandated. Instead, they based their existance on fear, patriotism, & an attitude that they knew what was good for us. Never, not once have they asked we travelers for suggestions, needs, or concerns.

I am sure frequent fliers would have been glad to offer them ideas & true security issues years ago, instead we were told what we needed & faced more and more "probing". All the while we were told to be quiet or you will miss your flight. THAT is not how to establish National Security.

If the courts go along with this total disrespect for citizen rights by the TSA, the 4th amendment of the Constitution will have lost any meaning. I'm surprised there isn't a greater outcry from the citizenry like a total boycott of flying until the TSA comes to its senses. I have stopped flying in the US because flying has become such an ordeal. Fortunately I live near Canada and when I want to vacation in Europe or Asia I can fly out of Vancouver, BC, where security is more sane.

I find it absurd that a country where people say they are so free have allowed an entire transportation industry to be turned into a penal zone where citizens have no rights. One could use the same logic that the TSA is using an require that all roads leading into all major cities have roadblock and that every vehicle entering any city be thoroughly searched. After all, one could pack a lot of explosives in a vehicle and detonate it downtown. It has happened before in the this country. But we don't do that. Why do we spend this inordinate amount of money and manpower at airports. I doubt there would be any more incidents if we had no security at airports. There has to be a better way than chucking the constitution and assuming that everyone is a criminal just because they want to fly from point A to point B.

The founders of this country who came up with guarantees of liberty such as the 4th Amendment did it in a very perilous time. Instead of coming up with a TSA or Patriot Act which gave the government unlimited power, they decided instead to guarantee citizens as much liberty as possible. We've come a long way where now safety is paramount and liberty means nothing. The founders of this country would not recognize this country as the one they started.

I was patted down on my first post-9/11 flight because I had purchased a one-way ticket I was told. It was humiliating beyond belief and left me in tears. Did I really need to unzip and flip over the top of my pants? I will not be flying again until the procedures change. And that will happen when the next terrorists successfully bring down another plane and it will be discovered that they went through the full body scanner and a pat down.

Fly only when it cannot be avoided.  Is there a place where the general public can get radiation badges?  It would be interesting to collect large scale data on exposure -- especially on frequent flyers. It could be crunched and posted on the internet.  You can be sure the TSA and "Homeland" "Security" will never release the data.

Wasn't sure how I would react the first time through the scanner, but found out quick enough. Felt like I was in a foreign country, where the government didn't give a hoot about their citizens and felt like they could do whatever they wanted. Bill of Rights? Government of the people for the people? Why, those are just words on an old piece of paper.

A number of comments here yearn for high speed rail. But terrorists can bomb trains a lot easier than planes, as they proved in London, Madrid, and Tokyo. TSA would set up shop in all stations after the first bombing. A better approach to airline security would be "random" searches. Would-be bombers would not know the real criteria, and infrequency of search would not give them the experience they need to learn to evade detection. After all, almost all experienced air travelers know what TSA does, and thus they can figure out how to beat it. Infrequent and constantly changing search procedures would deny the bad guys the knowledge of how to beat the system.

I would like to add that the private pat down for women by women in the India's Mumbai airport are very very respectful, and they should serve as the standard.  Pat downs should not be done in public in front of the entire population of travelers.

when in the world is the american public going to grow up and face reality? only 1% of the society is shouldering the burden of this conflict with the terrorists, and those complaining about inconveniencens at the airports are an embarassment to this country.
